title: Lazy Loading
subject: React
theory:
## On-Demand Components
React provides a built-in way to render dynamic imports as regular components.

### React.lazy
`const OtherComponent = React.lazy(() => import('./OtherComponent'));`

### Suspense
Since the code is loading over the network, React needs to show something meanwhile. Wrap lazy components in `<Suspense fallback={<Spinner />}>`.

common_mistakes.correction: Don't lazy load incidental UI (like buttons/icons). Use it for Routes or heavy Modals.

exam_notes: Only default exports supported by default.
summary: Lazy loading dramatically improves the 'Time to Interactive' metric.
